awd_titl_txt: LEAPS-MPS: Development of New Photoacid Catalyzed Reactions for Organic Synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).  In this project, funded by the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate and housed in the Chemistry Division, Professor Joseph Badillo and his students at Seton Hall University will study photoacids and photoacid catalysis to help design new chemical reactions that will be important in synthesizing new organic (carbon-based) molecules.  A photoacid is a weak acid in its normal state, and only upon irradiation with light does it become a strong acid, and thus catalytically active (able to speed up reactions).  This dependence on light-activation offers temporal- and spatial-control not possible with traditional acid catalysis. Despite the unique possibilities of photoacid catalysis, the synthesis and characterization of new photoacids and the development of new photoacid catalyzed reactions remains relatively unexplored.  Prof. Badillo also proposes a broadening participation plan that includes having his students present their research at URM-serving conferences such as NOBCChE, working with ACS Project SEED to provide research experiences for URM high school students, and working with several Seton Hall University student organizations to bring science outreach to local minority-serving high schools.

Professor Badillo will perform experiments leading to improved understanding of common photoacid catalysts’ photophysical properties by measuring excited state lifetimes (t) and acidities (pKa*).  A series of non-photoracemizable chiral photoacids will be designed, synthesized and characterized, and the use of photoacid catalysis will be explored in the context of C–X (X = H, O, C) bond-forming reactions, including asymmetric excited-state proton transfer, glycosylation, and acetalization reactions.  The use of photoacid generators such as halonium and sulfonium ions in the context of catalysis will also be investigated.  Prof. Badillo’s plan for integrating research and broadening participation-oriented outreach activities will both bring underrepresented minority high school students to Seton Hall University for research experiences, and send Seton Hall students into local schools for science outreach activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this project include: 1) The development of a mild visible light-activated acetalization. 2) The use of photoacid generators as catalysts for synthetic organic reactions. 3) The synthesis, design, and characterization of several second-generation photoacids. The photophysical properties of these photoacid structures have been studied using computational and spectroscopic techniques.

Our research has shown that several novel thiourea photoacids are readily accessible and absorb light in the visible region. These molecules have been characterized by UV-Vis and NMR spectroscopy, and mass spectrometry. Using computational chemistry, we have studied the effect of structural modifications on HOMO-LUMO gaps and frontier molecular orbital distribution. We have demonstrated that visible light photoactivation of 6-bromo-2-naphthol facilitates the photoacid-catalyzed acetalization of carbonyls with alcohols. When coupled to a photosensitizer, unsubstituted 2-naphthol is activated to provide the corresponding acetals. The S1 excited state pKa for 6-bromo-2-naphthol in water was determined and shown to have increased excited-state acidity relative to 2-naphthol.

The broader impacts of this research include: 1) The synthesis and study of novel photoacid molecules that could benefit society by finding use in new catalytic reactions and the development of new light-activated materials. 2) The training of next-generation scientists from traditionally underrepresented groups. 3) College-level research experiences for several high school students at Seton Hall University in collaboration with the ACS Project SEED Program. 4) STEM education for K-12 students at the 2022 and 2023 NJACS ChemExpos and the development of an annual STEM Education Visit to the Immaculate Conception High School in Montclair, NJ.

 


Last Modified: 12/11/2023
Modified by: Joseph J Badillo
